title: Before 2017, will Google announce that it will conduct public testing of its fully autonomous vehicles in a US city?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Even though the crowd says 1%, since I know nothing about this question, I shouldn't make such a risky forecast.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Google just pulled out of this project.
Dropping due to passage of time

On the WayMo rollout still bragging about letting one guy ride in the driverless car. Stated goal is L5 before public release, too little time left.

they're aleady runnning tests in pittsburgh. When will they announce?  Maybe mid-2017

No change, I heard the CEO of Alphabet and it seems that they love their self driving car projects, but they have not increase the budget for this upcoming year.

Google has made the point that they have the technology and know-how to accomplish autonomous driving.
Now, their goal is to sell the technology, no the cars! 
Google is going in the direction of technology development at the speed of light, but it is not a car company nor it is interested in being one. 
They already have cars -and built some of their own- on the road running autonomously, but the point is not to built the car is to build the technology and collect patents for sale!
In the know-how is where the big bucks are for google, not metal boxes.
Once the present technology is reduced to operate and look in a manner that make the car looks (no what people think is normal looking vehicle, not a mini humpback whale)  like any other car, then we will see another set of vehicles to test google software  and hardware capabilities. The present awkwardness of the technology is something they know people are still looking at what they are doing as science fiction, thus those google built mini boxes, they realized that problem of perception. Thus, they are using Lexus in their tests, still those Lexus have tons of hardware that makes them look like back to the future machine. That shall be overcome.

I think Google will not be in the business of making cars. They will probably license this technology to other car companies instead. Hence it does not make sense to have the public test its cars. More likely, the testing will be done via other car manufacturers.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
No news hinting at public testing in the October Monthly Report from Google.
Google is moving slowly with its AVs. They won't be inviting the public to try out their cars in the foreseeable future. Certainly not in the next 2 months.
Slowing investment, rearrangement into Alphabet-structure, recent interview with Google Moonshots SVP didn't provide good evidence, lack of discernible progress.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The race is on and they are well funded.
From what I have read, Google has autonomous cars on the public roads already.  Maybe I do not understand the question?
There are too many safety concerns, accidents reported, and various personnel changes for a Google announcement to occur in 2016.
Because of the accidents from the tesla cars.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

I am halving my previous forecast.  Although I do see a decent possibility of an announcement I am becoming more confident that Google will be spending their time arguing the case for autonomous driving in California and continue gathering data in their test cars throughout 2017.
Recent Uber AV accident in PA may influence Google? 4% to 0%.
I doubt that Google will make any move before 2017.
There are still a lot of regulatory and legal issues to overcome before Google will put a fully autonomous car on the roads given the potential liabilities involved.

Several crashes (including serious one) in September. CTO and other senior employees left in August - would likely want a full and bedded-in team prior to announcement. Would announcement distract from other google products (e.g. Home / Pixel) in run-up to Xmas? Plus regular comments that more work is needed / words to that effect ... all point to low probability of an announcement in due course.

- Don't see this fitting into Google's perf system which according to reports will close out in November, so big announcements will be stacked to the middle of the year so they can get a little traction
- Other manufacturers are trying outside the US so it seems logical for the big G to announce that first

Reduced forecast due to the lack of a serious roadmap to bring the tech to market.  Without that plan I believe they may continue to collect data, and watch the market.  Further competitors that have a long term plan are being more agressive in their efforts. Uber for example.

The favorable interest in Kirkland Washington from a social perspective, strong local government interest, and most importantly Googles partnership Chrysler for the fourth gen car manufactured to allow google to add their equipment easily.
Updating upwards in light of this: https://www.yahoo.com/news/driverless-cars-hit-british-streets-landmark-trial-005545714.html

There is no indication from Google that it will allow the general public to use its self-driving cars, as they emphasize the training and qualifications of their test drivers. Google is also not currently testing a public transport vehicle such as a bus. Furthermore there were multiple crashes in September and October, which furthe reduces the likelihood of public tests.
Unlikely given there are only two months left. But likely in 2017.

Another month with no real news--a design award. Their Google Plus group seems pretty dead. They don't seem like they're marketing their efforts, which they would need if they're getting ready for public testing.

Want to get out of this quickly?  Send an e-mail to Google asking, "Will you conduct public testing of your fully autonomous vehicles in a US city?"   Unless they say No or Undecided (or don't respond at all), this resolves as a Yes, since a Yes or a Yes-But would be an announcement to this effect "before 2017."

The technology is getting close.  Although Alphabet is reportedly not ready to turn the vehicles loose on the streets, 2 million miles of autonomous driving are now history.  As these cars still have driver controls, and California law specifies only a very limited area for autonomous vehicles, suspect that we will need to see a. Few more milestones passed before this question could end with a positive outcome.  
http://www.theverge.com/2016/10/5/13164406/google-self-driving-car-2-million-miles-alphabet-x

I don't know anything about this. It just seems unlikely that it will happen in the next 3 months, which is a short period of time. I'm guessing that people are tending to be overconfident due to duration neglect.

I don't know anything about this. It just seems unlikely that it will happen in the next 3 months, which is a short period of time. I'm guessing that people are tending to be overconfident due to duration neglect.

The race is heating up. Singapore is allowing for a testing. California is now allowing 15 companies to test in the state including Chinese web services rival Baidu. If they don't announce this year, they are only interested in selling the platform and not cars

Google will focus its' marketing on the new phone for Christmas season. Seems rather unlikely that they will draw attention away from the phone for a product that will not be available for another few years.
this is still much work need to be done.  it is still early stage of the product dev.  especially it is very early on its release to the market since it will deal with law and insurance,...
A low Zero forecast, when Google can easily make any announcement, over any timeframe, may be too low.
I misread the question: I assumed the question meant before 2017 was over. Rereading this its clearly by Dec 31, 2016
CA recently signed a bill into law allowing the testing of fully autonomous vehicles for 6 months (http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB1592).
Considering my new understanding of "public testing" and the recent Google AV accidents I have a new question.  What is Google’s risk appetite to keep up with Uber?

Autonomous car regulations were just updated in California, and though they aren't 100% finalized they could pave the way for live testing. Whether or not google moves that quickly remains to be seen. They might not announce, and could just have a few cars out on the road.

Going below  consensus, I didn't consider that google hasn't much to gain from a public testing (unlike Uber).

Google is obviously busy testing & researching its autonomous vehicles.  However, it is facing a number of obstacles in the near term - new safety regulations and a number of minor accidents involving their cars in the real world.  I think that a Google announcement for fully autonomous vehicles in a US city will likely come at a later date (after Jan. 1, 2017).
Tesla, they need to wait for the autopilot dust to settle
although it's just an announcement that is required...there seems to be be more obstacles than meets the eye.
There seem to be legal libality related impediments besides technical difficulties in this whole automatic driving car projects,

There has been a lot of turnover on Google's Autonomous Vehicle project, but California seems to be ready to pass regulations that will allow autonomous vehicles to operate. The issue is when that regulation will pass. Considering that it is an election year, this process will likely be slowed until after the elections. By that time, Thanksgiving will be coming and then Christmas right after that. When will they get together will cities to make this happen? The only reason this is not lower is because all they need to do is announce it and not do the actual testing until later in 2017. It seems unlikely, but possible.

-70%
Concord city council met last night and it seems GoMentum station is a hot topic.  Also Gomentum Station is an exclusive testing ground excluding google.  But "Google, Apple, other manufacturers have approached us and we've taken a look at maybe partnering with these companies to begin their testing here, at least in California, in Concord, at the GoMentum Station".
Still too many regulatory regulatory hurdles for a fully autonomous public testing to be announced  within the next three months.

How do we get a clarification on this question? Does public mean people buy the car, or lease it, or does Google loan the car? 
**What makes a trial "public" here?**
How many places or streets would it have to run on? How limited would the sign up process be? 
They're adding cars, but I don't see evidence that they're getting ready for a public trial. 
Also, they're capped at 25 miles per hour. 
Finally, they're restrained spending on Google Fiber because of cost. Unless they feel pressured to keep up with Tesla, what motive do they have for a trial before the end of 2016?
I'll leave it at 3% based on the idea that they're something happening behind closed doors.

One grows tired of trying to decipher what these Qs mean.  As worded, assuming English is the language in which we are working, this is a Yes if on December 31, 2016--or for that matter, tomorrow morning--Google announces,  "We will conduct public testing of our fully autonomous vehicles in a US city," and says nary another word on the topic until the sun has expanded past the orbit of Mars.  That is almost certainly not what anyone wants to know, since it contains no information of any earthly (or Martian) use to anyone.
Tenuous estimation. It's reasonable that the announcement will be made for the implementation of public testing next year.

Google has been publicly asking the federal government to step in and create regulations that would allow a fully driverless car without a steering wheel, brake pedal, or supervising driver to hit the roads.NHTSA is keeping the door open for the kind of reality Google is envisioning.
Consensus which has been consistently and wrongly pro Google is at 28%. Justifies halving my confidence level.

I wanted to find "recent"language where Google discussed "fully self-driving cars".  Also this document reports both collisions while in manual and autonomous mode.  It seems the recent collision in Mountain View is not a new phenomena or a big deal.
Wrong time of year (4th quarter) to launch a public transportation test.
Congratulations to GJOpen for providing useful definitions with the Q.
Google announced they were operating a "Google self-driving car" in Mountain View, California.  Thanks @Dsarin for posting the link first! +1 upvote for you.

A Google self-driving car was involved in crash in Mt. View today
https://techcrunch.com/2016/09/23/a-google-self-driving-car-crashed-in-mt-view-today/

The August monthly report published by Google contains significantly more accident reports than the months of July, June, and May 2016. The Google-designed vehicles also went from the "Google Autonomous Vehicle (Google AV)" in May-July to being called "prototype vehicle" in the August report. These observations may indicate a significant design change, implementation of new sensors/electronics, or software updates that have taken the project to the next milestone, but not a public test ready prototype. Google may "announce" public testing before Jan 1 2017, but for PR and media purposes, not as an actual timeline.
Not much time left in the year; Google has more important things to worry about.
five accidents in August according to the latest report. unless the rate gets to zero or one, seems too risky.
Didn't fully read the description.   Yes if Mountain View counts as a US City.
want to wait until new admin
Bloomberg spent considerable time yesterday reporting things going on with AV.  +1
All the other brands are testing. It is important for google to keep up.

Still a long way to go before these things are ready for the general public. For Bay Area Google employees, perhaps. For public access Google will need to build systems for reservations, ride tracking, customer service, etc. Uber had all these systems in place for their existing (non-autonomous ride-sharing) service long before they launched their self-driving car experiment in Pittsburg.

- Assumption: Uber is testing in Pittsburgh (not 100% certain if they are "fully" autonomous), Lyft got bullish as well
- Google has released Waze
Tesla has already done it and Baidau has done it in China. It is time for Google to catch up.

According to today's news The Obama administration's proposed guidelines for Self-Driving Cars, include15 Benchmarks automakers will need to meet before their autonomous vehicles can hit the road. http://bloom.bg/2cz5mgB
That doesn't necessarily means that Google/Alphabet could not conduct a public "testing" before 2017, actually Uber debuted its First Fleet of driverless cars in Pittsburgh 3 days ago, http://bloom.bg/2bzThsU but makes it harder for sure.

There is a large push from automakers as well as ride sharing services to break into this market first. Uber has already tested out vehicles in other countries. It only makes sense for Google to start sooner rather than later. They have tested their technology longer and have only the hurdle of public opinion and possibly lawmakers.

AlphaBet's Google in favor of Fed regs to prevent difference between states.  Competition may require testing, although they may give the Feds a chance to give some direction.

going to 99% until earnings.  3rdQ Earnings would be the best time to announce.  From a different perspective....the purpose of a publicly traded company to announce something is to attract talent and money.
I am net positive on the technology but I think that lawmakers would be reluctant to associate themselves with such legislation too early.

While Google is more advanced than Uber and others in self driving technology I believe they are building a platform and OS to enable this.  So, they have plenty of additional 'private' work to do before either Google, or a Google partner, makes the technology available as part of a business.  Technology is getting close...go to market strategy is lacking  -
Now that Uber is testing driverless taxis in Pittsburgh and Ford is making more noise about autonomy, they will need to do something to keep up.
Very unlikely based on Google policy so far.

This question must have been hacked in--it includes a remarkably cogent and almost complete description of what it means.  (It doesn't entirely clarify whether a "public test" must take place on public streets, or whether it's a Yes if members of the public can drive out to a special facility and give it a try; I am assuming the former.)
Things are speeding up and google is an early trend setter.  I think they will announce it this year, but it probably won't begin until next year.
it's time and they've got the tech
Technology is ready, public is ready, and some city will want the notoriety.
Uber's public testing in Pittsburgh will accelerate Google's testing

Autonomous driving depending heavily on image processing. It is indispensable that in one millisecond with 99,9 % accuracy a scenery can be understood by image processing but the best heuristics for image processing  have an accuracy by 80% of Company google.

In December 2015, the California Department of Motor Vehicles issued long-anticipated proposed regulations governing autonomous vehicles, and invited public comments on the draft regulations at meetings in Sacramento on January 28, 2016, and in Los Angeles on February 2, 2016. If adopted, the regulations would require self-driving cars to have a steering wheel and pedals, and a human driver onboard who holds an "autonomous vehicle operator certificate." They would also hold the occupant responsible for accidents and violations of traffic laws, regardless of whether or not they were at the wheel.

Though the Google car project just lost its director, Chris Urmson, it has a big head start on Uber and others. Its leaders have suggested they could launch public pilot tests of cars with no steering wheels or pedals in the next year or two.
http://www.news.com.au/technology/innovation/motoring/uber-users-in-pittsburgh-are-about-to-be-given-the-option-to-hail-driverless-cars/news-story/d0a8e98eaa114f6ad429bd16b9a21278

It seems the next step for google is driving full AV in a US city.  It also looks like google within the last 3 days placed 40 positions (for hire) for the AV project.  Considering Google is a publicly traded company it would make sense to get more bang for the buck.  That means I suspect an "announcement" would come just before or during quarterly earnings.  The next earnings for Google is within the next couple weeks (27 Sept 2016 estimated).  Also considering Google (GOOG) stock price near all time highs, uncertainty of the FED and GOOG monthly chart indicating distribution I suspect an announcement could come in the next couple weeks.  A breakout of google above all time highs could pay for the entire AV public testing.  Starting out at 70%.
